tossups.question: Albert Edward Wiggam toured the US to promote this ideology, claiming that it would lead to a “new decalogue.” Harry Haiselden wrote and starred in a film loosely based on his actions taken to further this ideology. “Capper Medals” were given at events in Kansas supporting this ideology, which had been inspired by similar events begun by Mary de Gormo. To better support this ideology, several photos of children were retouched to make them look scarier in Henry H. Goddard’s (*) The Kallikak Family. In addition to racism, this ideology led to Elaine Riddick being one of many women subjected to “Mississippi appendectomies.” This ideology was supported in a case where Oliver Wendell Holmes’s ruling stated that “Three generations of imbeciles are enough.” For 10 points, Buck v. Bell advanced what ideology of seeking to “improve” the human gene pool by controlling reproduction?
tossups.formatted_answer: eugenics [prompt on birth control, family planning, or compulsory sterilization with “What ideology was that practice meant to support?”]
tossups.answer: eugenics [prompt on birth control, family planning, or compulsory sterilization with “What ideology was that practice meant to support?”]

tossups.question: In a novel set in this city, a doctor staggers out of a woman’s house with a bloody head wound inflicted by the woman’s servant, who suspected them of having an affair. Before he moved to Japan, Lafcadio Hearn spent a decade as a chronicler of this city. After moving back to this city, the protagonist of a novel spends all her time painting in her attic and neglects all household duties, including receiving visitors on Tuesdays. After his family dies of yellow fever, Joseph (*) Frowenfeld moves from Philadelphia to this city in a novel in which his patient Palmyre stabs Agricola for coordinating the capture and lynching of the slave Bras Coupe. The Grandissimes is set in this city, whose nearby barrier island of Grand Isle is where Robert Lebrun first meets Edna Pontellier. For 10 points, the late 19th century authors George Washington Cable and Kate Chopin documented Creole life in what Southern city?
tossups.formatted_answer: New Orleans [or NOLA; or The Big Easy; or La Nouvelle-Orléans]
tossups.answer: New Orleans [or NOLA; or The Big Easy; or La Nouvelle-Orléans]

tossups.question: One of these compounds linked to the 3’ [three prime] end of a template triggers premature release from the A site of a ribosome in mRNA display. Paper disks coated with these compounds are used in the Kirby-Bauer test. In a common inducible gene expression system, a transactivator protein engineered from the herpes simplex virus protein VP16 can only bind to its response element in the presence of one of these compounds. Cell culture media is often supplemented with a 1% (*) mixture of two of these compounds. A dilution series of these compounds in LB broth can be prepared in an assay to measure their minimum inhibitory concentrations. Positive selection in cloning is usually achieved by designing plasmids which encode enzymes that degrade these compounds, such as beta-lactamases. For 10 points, cloning with E. coli often exploits the bacteria’s innate lack of resistance to what drugs?
tossups.formatted_answer: antibiotics [or aminonucleosides; or tetracyclines; or beta-lactams before “beta-lactamase”; or aminoglycosides; accept puromycin; accept doxycycline; accept penicillin; accept streptomycin]
tossups.answer: antibiotics [or aminonucleosides; or tetracyclines; or beta-lactams before “beta-lactamase”; or aminoglycosides; accept puromycin; accept doxycycline; accept penicillin; accept streptomycin]

tossups.question: In one tradition, this god was described as "starry-bodied" when he took his "place on the folds of Parnassus" and was equated to Iacchus. Plutarch claimed that the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles was actually a festival dedicated to this god, and that the Sabbath was dedicated to a Phrygian analogue of him named Sabazius. The immortality of this god was commemorated with sacrifices using a kantharos. During the Lenaia festival, this god was honored with a hymn and dance called the (*) dithyramb. This god was identified with a son of Zeus and Persephone named Zagreus by followers of the Orphic mysteries. Followers of this god may have practiced omophagia, or the eating of raw flesh from dismembered animals. This deity was depicted holding a thyrsus staff and was followed by satyrs and sileni. The Maenads were the priestesses of, for 10 points, what Greek god of wine?
tossups.answer: Dionysus [or Bacchus]

tossups.question: A lion's head and a minotaur’s skin are shown next to a man inspecting a rainbow dodecahedron above a depiction of this city in Andre Masson’s Iconic Views of [this city]. A “Blind Man of [this city]” is depicted walking along St. Martin Bridge in one painting. An artist from this city showed the Virgin Mary placing a robe on Saint Ildephonsus above a depiction of himself holding a map in a painting partially titled for the Plan of [this city]. The artist of Quince, Cabbage, Melon, and Cucumber primarily worked in this city and developed the (*) bodegón genre. This hometown of Juan Sanchéz Cotan is shown underneath a blue stormy sky next to the castle of San Servando in one depiction. The Iglesia de Santo Tomé in this city holds the Burial of the Count of Orgaz. For 10 points, identify this Spanish city, the subject of a Mannerist “view” by El Greco.
tossups.answer: Toledo, Spain

tossups.question: This operation applied to the Maxwell stress tensor is equal to the force per unit volume on the electromagnetic field plus one over c squared times the time rate of change of the Poynting vector. Applying this operation to r-hat over r-squared in spherical coordinates results in 4 pi times a cubic Dirac delta function. The negative time derivative of the energy density of an electromagnetic field is equal to the dot product of the current density and the electric field (*) plus this operation applied to the Poynting vector.  In the Coulomb gauge, the result of this operation is set equal to zero. The negative time derivative of charge density equals this operation performed on the current density. Applying this operation to the electric field yields the charge density divided by permittivity of free space according to  Gauss’ Law. For 10 points, name this vector calculus operation symbolized “del dot.”
tossups.answer: divergence [prompt on del dot before mentioned]

tossups.question: One philosopher argued against the “Benjamin Franklin Objection” to these concepts by saying that natural processes are not necessarily morally correct. The “rational” approach to arguing against these concepts is compared to a man named Jones not attending college because he can’t read in a paper by James Rachels. Roger Scruton laid out three different relationships within these concepts that, if mixed together, would lead to the adoption of immense “burdens of morality.” (*) Tom Regan presented a version of the argument from marginal cases by claiming that the subjects of these concepts are “subjects-of-a-life” and “moral patients.” Utilitarian arguments for the reduction of suffering are used by Peter Singer to support, for 10 points, what concept, the idea that non-human creatures are owed moral consideration and respect?
tossups.formatted_answer: animal rights [accept any answer indicating the belief that non-human animals should be given moral rights; accept Animal Rights and Wrongs; prompt on just rights] (The first line is referring to an argument made by Peter Singer in Animal Liberation)
tossups.answer: animal rights [accept any answer indicating the belief that non-human animals should be given moral rights; accept Animal Rights and Wrongs; prompt on just rights] (The first line is referring to an argument made by Peter Singer in Animal Liberation)

tossups.question: A poem in this genre notes “On the farm, it's cold and rustic — no place for a girl” and begins with its speaker complaining that “my stupid birthday’s here.” In a comic poem of this type, a woman’s ghost rebukes the speaker for not grieving enough at her funeral. A woman commands her husband to “no longer burden my grave with tears” in the last part of an author’s fourth book of these poems. An author originated the saying “absence makes the heart grow fonder” in one of his 92 poems of this type, the first book of which was separately published as (*) Cynthia Monobiblos. This format was used in the six surviving poems by the female poet Sulpicia and in a poem that ends with the words “ave atque vale.” A line of hexameter followed by a line of pentameter made up the constituent couplets of, for 10 points, what poetic form whose classical varieties did not necessarily have a mournful tone?
tossups.formatted_answer: elegies [or elegy; or elegiac couplets; the second through fourth sentences refer to Propertius]
tossups.answer: elegies [or elegy; or elegiac couplets; the second through fourth sentences refer to Propertius]

tossups.question: Franz Liszt used his influence over the Staatskapelle Weimar to arrange for this opera’s premiere under the baton of Eduard Lassen. This opera begins with one of the title characters trying to raise the morale of a group of slaves by singing “Arretez, o mes Freres,” but his attempts are interrupted by the arrival of a villainous government official. In an oft-excerpted dance from this opera, the oboe plays an iconic opening solo marked ad libitum over an A major pizzicato chord played by the strings. This opera features two of the most popular arias in the mezzo-soprano repertoire, (*) “Printemps qui commence” and “Mon coeur s’ouvre a ta voix.” This opera ends when one of the title characters destroys the Temple of Dagon with his divine strength. The Danse Bacchanale appears in, for 10 points, which opera by Camille Saint-Saens about a hero from the Book of Judges whose strength is linked to his hair?
tossups.answer: Samson and Delilah [or Samson et Dalila]

tossups.question: The story of a woman of the Lemdha clan who was imprisoned for 21 years for attempting to aid a resistance movement in this region is told in her autobiography Sorrow Mountain. Though the number is likely exaggerated, a traditional account claims that a bombing run that killed 4,000 civilians ended a siege of a complex at Litang in this region. A resistance group known as the “Four Rivers, Six Ranges” from this region operated out of another country’s Mustang region for as long as they received (*) CIA funding. This region was formally annexed with the Seventeen Points Agreement. Protests in this region in March 1959 ended with the bombing of Potala Palace and the flight of its leader to India. For 10 points, name this region now controlled by China, which was once governed by the Dalai Lama.
tossups.answer: Tibet [accept Bod; accept Xīzàng; accept Tibetan Plateau; prompt on Himalayas]

tossups.question: After its author learned that copies of this book were destroyed by the publisher Maunsel & Roberts, he depicted an editor using the ashes to sign the cross on his ass in the scathing poem “Gas from a Burner.” The author explained that he organized this book to go from depicting earlier to later stages of life in a letter to his brother Stanislaus. At the start of this book, the narrator announces a priest’s fatal third stroke and recalls softly saying the word (*) "paralysis" to himself. This book initially ended with a story of a man who injures his tongue after falling down the stairs of a pub, but its author later added a long story that ends with a man hearing snow “faintly falling… upon all the living and the dead” after his wife Gretta tells him of being serenaded in her youth by Michael Furey. “Grace” and “The Dead” are the final two stories of, for 10 points, what collection by James Joyce?
tossups.answer: Dubliners

tossups.question: Duke philosopher Toril Moi highlighted Simone de Beauvoir’s claim in The Second Sex that this entity is “not a thing,” but instead “a situation” that forms a key part of a lived experience. Frantz Fanon concluded Black Skin, White Masks by pleading with one of these entities to “always make me a man who questions!” These entities title a book whose second portion includes readings of Willa Cather, Nella Larsen, and the film Paris is Burning. Midcentury phenomenologists refer to awareness of the spatial orientation of these entities as their namesake (*) “schema.” Michel Foucault popularized discussing these entities in the context of the spaces they inhabit. In a 1993 book about the “discursive limits of sex,” Judith Butler wrote about these entities That Matter. Academic texts often describe the violence done to queer, female, and black examples of, for 10 points, what corporeal objects, whose “image” may be “positive” for someone who feels good about their appearance?
tossups.formatted_answer: bodies [or the body; or the female body; or the black body; or the queer body; or body schema; or body image; or body positivity; or Bodies That Matter]
tossups.answer: bodies [or the body; or the female body; or the black body; or the queer body; or body schema; or body image; or body positivity; or Bodies That Matter]

tossups.question: After its leader was lured away with the prospect of a business deal, Gernot Pütz and two Dutch “businessmen” commandeered an installation on this body of water for five days. Greece donated 500 tons of raisins to a city impacted by a 1962 flood of this body of water. Growing economic activity in this body of water necessitated expanding facilities at Sullom Voe in the late 1970’s. To circumvent a country’s restrictions, a ship anchored in this body of water was where the [emphasize] first Radio (*) Caroline broadcasts originated. The slogan “Bring the men up now” was central to protests following the 1988 Piper Alpha disaster in this body of water. Economic interest in this body of water expanded with the discovery of energy sources called West Sole and Ekofisk. For 10 points, name this body of water, whose fossil fuel resources have been exploited by the UK and Norway.
tossups.answer: North Sea

tossups.question: A sixth century vagabond who was nicknamed for carrying one of these creatures under his arm wrote a poem about beheading a female one of them after she rebuffed his advances. These creatures, whose name means “to seize,” are often conflated with a class of entirely-female beings called the sila. One of these creatures is fatally struck on the waist by a sword, then tries to trick his killer into hitting him a second time, which would revive him, in a tale from the (*) One Thousand and One Nights. The hooves of asses are a key identifying feature of these children of Iblis. In folklore, these creatures are often depicted stalking deserts in the guise of attractive women or hanging around cemeteries to feed on dead bodies. For 10 points, name these undead creatures from Arabian folklore whose name is used derogatorily in English to refer to people who revel in human suffering.
tossups.answer: ghul [or ghulah; or ghouls; prompt on djinn]

tossups.question: In 2018, researchers studying one of these compounds with a boron-oxygen-boron bridge identified a new form of isomerism they called akamptisomerism [AY-kampt-eye-SAW-myr-izm]. Examples of these compounds with high steric bulk on one side are known as their “picket-fence” type. These compounds can partly be synthesized from four aldehydes in the one-pot Rothemund reaction. The circular order of the four methyl, two vinyl, and two propionic acid substituents of one of these molecules is the reason why it is suffixed with a (*) Roman numeral IX. Glycine reacts with succinyl-CoA to form delta-aminolevulinic acid in the committed step for the biosynthesis of these compounds, which consist of four pyrrole subunits. These compounds have one more linking carbon group than corrins such as vitamin B12, and are partially hydrogenated in chlorins such as chlorophyll. For 10 points, name these ring-shaped compounds, one of which is coordinated to an iron atom in heme.
tossups.formatted_answer: porphyrins [or porphin; or protoporphyrins; or picket-fence porphyrins; prompt on heme or hemoglobin with “What class of compounds is that an example of?” before “heme”]
tossups.answer: porphyrins [or porphin; or protoporphyrins; or picket-fence porphyrins; prompt on heme or hemoglobin with “What class of compounds is that an example of?” before “heme”]

tossups.question: Each February, this city hosts a winter festival whose mascot is a snowman with arrows and a multi-colored sash named Bonhomme Carnaval. This city is home to one of its country's five sacred shrines, whose entrance is lined with seven 6-foot Joseph-Émile Brunet sculptures. In addition to the Basilica of Sainte-Anne-de-Beaupré, this city contains the Terrasse Dufferin, which overlooks this city's Lower Town. This city's skyline is dominated by a "grand railway hotel" known as the (*) Château Frontenac. This city's "Breakneck Stairs" are located in the shopping district of Petit Champlain. The Cap-Diamant in this city is home to the only fortified city walls in the Western Hemisphere north of Mexico. This city was home to a set of uniquely snowproof Martello towers on the Plains of Abraham. For 10 points, name this capital of a French-speaking Canadian Province.
tossups.answer: Quebec City

tossups.question: Along with tourmaline and rutile, a mineral named for this element names an “index” used to find how weathered a sedimentary rock is. This element’s tungstate is used to study negative thermal expansion because it exhibits such behavior below 1000K. A deposit of a mineral named for this element found in the Jack Hills in Western Australia is named for forming in the Hadean era, making it the oldest surviving material of Earthly origin. Uranium-lead dating most commonly takes place on deposits of this element’s silicate. A lead titanate containing this element is the most commonly used (*) piezoelectric ceramic. Thermal conductivity is used to differentiate the “cubic” form of this element’s dioxide from diamonds. For 10 points, identify this transition metal placed under titanium and above hafnium on the periodic table with atomic number 40.
tossups.answer: zirconium [accept Zr]

tossups.question: In a film by this director, a man uncovers the corpse of a woman while skipping rocks in a riverbed. The color gradually fades to black and white as the protagonist of another film by this director dons a black leather jacket and double-barreled revolver to hunt for an evil school teacher. This director intended to evoke Apollo with the exaggerated yoga poses struck by one of his villains, who tricks a man into thinking a remote controls his pacemaker. In that film, this director employed a continuous tracking shot that shows a man with a (*) knife in his back using a hammer to beat up thugs in a hallway. This director’s Sympathy for Mr. Vengeance and Lady Vengeance form a trilogy with his film in which Oh Dae-su unwittingly sleeps with his own daughter after being locked in a hotel room for fifteen years. For 10 points, name this South Korean director of Oldboy.
tossups.answer: Park Chan-Wook

tossups.question: A major American collection of sources from this general time period was assembled by Bella da Costa Greene, a black librarian forced to pass as white. A prestigious journal for studies of this period, Speculum, takes its name from a genre of encyclopedic literature first written during this era. The growing political use of this time period is exemplified by the recent feud between the scholars Dorothy Kim and Rachel Fulton Brown. A historian specializing in this time period, (*) Marc Bloch, wrote his dissertation on the belief that monarchs cured illnesses by laying on hands. This era is traditionally divided into Early, High, and Late periods, and scholars no longer view the first of those periods as an era of cultural regression known as the “Dark Ages.” For 10 points, name this period of European history before the Renaissance.
tossups.formatted_answer: Middle Ages [or the medieval era; accept Early, High, and Late Middle Ages; prompt on Dark Ages before “Dark Ages” is mentioned]
tossups.answer: Middle Ages [or the medieval era; accept Early, High, and Late Middle Ages; prompt on Dark Ages before “Dark Ages” is mentioned]

tossups.question: In a 2018 study, an author from this family identified Samuel Johnson as the architect of an “English metaphysical empire.” An author from this family described the ordeals faced by 99 suitors in their quest to become the progenitors of nine clans in a 2020 verse epic, for which he became the first person nominated for the International Man Booker as both author and translator. In a comic novel, that author from this family wrote about the quest of a despot to fund the construction of a (*) “superwonder” of the world called Marching to Heaven. Mukoma, a member of this family who wrote The Rise of the African Novel, is the son of a writer who explained his decision to abandon writing in English in Decolonizing the Mind. That author with this surname wrote about Mugo’s betrayal of the resistance fighter Kihika in his best-known novel. For 10 points, give this surname of the Kenyan author of A Grain of Wheat.
tossups.formatted_answer: Ngũgĩ [or Ngũgĩ wa Thiong’o; or James Ngugi; or Mũkoma wa Ngũgĩ]
tossups.answer: Ngũgĩ [or Ngũgĩ wa Thiong’o; or James Ngugi; or Mũkoma wa Ngũgĩ]

bonuses.leadin: Apache Spark was released in response to the limitations of this paradigm. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this algorithm paradigm used to process large amounts of data in parallel. This paradigm first processes the data into key-value pairs and sorts it, and then performs some function and aggregates the result.

Researchers Jeffrey Dean and Sanjay Ghemawat from this company proposed the MapReduce paradigm. This tech company’s search engine uses the PageRank algorithm, which puns on the name of its co-founder Larry Page.

MapReduce-based algorithms can be used for dimension processing and fact processing to this database process. This process with a generic three-word name collects data from various sources, transforms the data according to business rules, and then loads it into a destination data store.
answers: ETL [or extract, transform, and load; accept in any order]

bonuses.leadin: In the standpoint theory of this field, an individual's positionality and perspective is the grounding of authority on certain topics. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this philosophical field, whose social type argues that knowledge is a collective achievement formed through testimony, disagreement, and group attribution. This field is commonly defined as the study of knowledge.

This Panamanian-American philosopher has helped develop the field of social epistemology. She defined the title concepts as "historical formations" in her book Visible Identities and attacked the language used in media to describe sexual assaults in Rape and Resistance.

In Real Knowledge, Alcoff put forward a "new version" of this theory of truth grounded in social epistemology. This theory holds that truth can only be held by entire systems of statements, in contrast to foundationalism.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about the literary appearances of the phrase, “He who laughs last, laughs best.”
parts: The phrase may have originated from an early Jacobean play titled for a Prince of this holiday. Jacob Marley’s ghost is one of the many spirits that appear in an 1843 novella about this holiday.

After he is asked to help his sister-in-law, Mr. Barnard calms himself down by saying the phrase in this author’s play The Country House. This author’s play The Relapse is a sequel to Colley Cibber’s play Love’s Last Shift.

This work ends with the title character, called “Him” throughout the work, saying the phrase. This philosophical dialogue is set in the Regency Café where the narrator likes to watch people play chess.
answers: Christmas [accept The Christmas Prince or A Christmas Carol]
Rameau’s Nephew, or the Second Satire [or The Nephew of Rameau; or Le Neveu de Rameau ou La Satire seconde] (by Denis Diderot)
formatted_answers: Rameau’s Nephew, or the Second Satire [or The Nephew of Rameau; or Le Neveu de Rameau ou La Satire seconde] (by Denis Diderot)

bonuses.leadin: A photographer from this country showed a man covered in black and white spots of paint holding a burning candle in a depiction of the god of smallpox, Sonponnoi. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this country home to the father of a Young British Artist who incorporated elephant dung into a depiction of a Black Madonna.

Another ethnically Nigerian artist, Yinka Shonibare, used headless mannequins covered in Ankara fabric in a sculptural adaptation of this Fragonard painting which depicts a woman kicking on the title conveyance.

This man became the first African-born curator of the Venice Biennale in 2015. This Nigerian curator rose to prominence after his 1996 Guggenheim show In/Sight, one of the first explicitly postcolonial art shows.
answers: The Swing [accept Happy Accidents of the Swing; accept Les Hasards heureux de l'escarpolette]
formatted_answers: The Swing [accept Happy Accidents of the Swing; accept Les Hasards heureux de l'escarpolette]

bonuses.leadin: During a court case resolved in 2006, an advocacy group for the rights of peoples in this region appealed to celebrities like Leonardo di Caprio, Ludacris, and Snoop Dogg. For 10 points each:
parts: The organization First People of [this region] and the Nyae Nyae [NIGH-NIGH] Conservancy have fought for indigenous land rights in which natural region?
These peoples were among several evicted from the Central Kalahari Game Reserve in the 1990s. These traditionally nomadic peoples are often grouped with the Khoekhoe.
The San were recruited as scouts and trackers [emphasize] against this cause, which was sought after by SWAPO.
answers: San peoples [accept Khoisan; accept Bushmen; accept Basarwa]

bonuses.leadin: Doctor Fine sends agents codenamed for Western watches to murder people disseminating these objects in Orhan Pamuk’s novel The New Life. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these objects. Ermes Marana introduces bizarre errors into another of these objects in a metafictional novel whose protagonist investigates their defects.
You sit down to read a copy of this Italian author’s If on a winter’s night a traveler in his second-person novel with that title.

This unfinished novel, which also shares its title with the novel it appears in, is criticized by the psychoanalyst Mme Sophroniska for being excessively abstract. Its author makes the most progress on it after he and his nephew first have sex, and essentially abandons it after his nephew’s suicide attempt.
answers: a book that shares its title with, and is implied to be the same as, the novel it appears in [or a novel]
The Counterfeiters [or Les Faux-monnayeurs] (by André Gide)
formatted_answers: a book that shares its title with, and is implied to be the same as, the novel it appears in [or a novel]

bonuses.leadin: Ward Churchill invented an 1837 incident involving these objects, resulting in him being fired from the University of Colorado Boulder. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these objects, which Churchill claimed were shipped from St. Louis to be distributed at Fort Clark. These objects were used in a derogatory name for Native Americans who did not assimilate after boarding school.

After the death of a member of this tribe, they held two Americans hostage, prompting the US Navy to bombard Angoon when they couldn’t provide 400 blankets. This tribe had earlier failed to halt Russian settlement at the Battle of Sitka.
Two blankets and a handkerchief were intentionally infected with this disease during the Siege of Fort Pitt as part of Jeffery Amherst’s efforts to “extirpate” Native Americans.
answers: blankets [accept “blanket Indian”; accept, but DO NOT otherwise reveal, smallpox blankets]
Tlingit [accept Kootznoowoo Tlingit or Xootsnoowú Ḵwáan; accept Kiks.ádi Tlingit]
formatted_answers: blankets [accept “blanket Indian”; accept, but DO NOT otherwise reveal, smallpox blankets]

bonuses.leadin: Enthusiasts of this hobby use the acronyms LBM and BWM to refer to nondescript agaric objects. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this activity whose participants might use field guides to identify teeth, pores, or gills to avoid objects like Amanita.
In Poland, Belarus, Ukraine, and Russia, hunters have to be aware of mushrooms that accumulated cesium-137 as a result of this 1986 disaster.

An unpleasant smell often described as “cinnamon and gym socks” is given off by this prized mushroom native to Japanese coniferous forests. Its symbiosis with the forest floor is used as a metaphor for human interdependence with nature in Anna Tsing’s 2015 book The Mushroom at the End of the World.
answers: mushroom hunting [or mushroom picking; or synonyms; LBM stands for “little brown mushroom” and BWM stands for “big white mushroom”]
formatted_answers: mushroom hunting [or mushroom picking; or synonyms; LBM stands for “little brown mushroom” and BWM stands for “big white mushroom”]

bonuses.leadin: This quantity can be measured by adding an indicator electrolyte such as cadmium chloride in the moving boundary method. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity, sometimes named for German physicist Johann Hittorf, which indicates what fraction of a given current is carried in a given electrolyte by each ion.
These two ions have especially high transport numbers, because they “jump” through solutions in a mechanism described by Grotthus. The negative logs of their concentrations add up to 14.

At zero concentration, the ion transport number can be expressed in terms of the “limiting molar” versions of this quantity for cations, anions, and electrolytes. It’s typically measured in microsiemens per centimeter.
answers: H+ [or hydrogen ion; proton; or H3O+; or hydronium] and OH- [or hydroxide ion]
limiting molar conductivity [reject “conductance,” which is measured in Siemens]
formatted_answers: limiting molar conductivity [reject “conductance,” which is measured in Siemens]

bonuses.leadin: The perception of high levels of parental criticism and expectations are two dimensions included on a scale for this trait developed by Randy Frost. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this trait, which was divided by Don Hamachek into a maladaptive "neurotic" type and an adaptive "normal" type. Later studies found that the "normal" type of this trait predicted depression and eating disorders.

High levels of perfectionism are a characteristic symptom of this condition, also characterized by an excessive desire for orderliness and neatness. It is frequently confused with an anxiety disorder that involves ritualistic routines such as hand washing.
High levels of perfectionism are also correlated with this behavior, which was divided into types such as fatalistic and altruistic in a landmark methodological study by Emile Durkheim.
answers: obsessive compulsive personality disorder [or OCPD; or compulsive personality disorder; reject "obsessive compulsive disorder" or "OCD"]
formatted_answers: obsessive compulsive personality disorder [or OCPD; or compulsive personality disorder; reject "obsessive compulsive disorder" or "OCD"]

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about operas for literal children, for 10 points each.
parts: This 19th century composer wrote four operas based on fairytales: Little Red Riding Hood, The Snow-Bogatyr, Ivan the Fool, and Puss in Boots, which is the best known of the set.
Productions often emphasize the family friendly nature of this Leos Janacek opera about an animal that escapes from a forester who captures her and makes her his pet.
Engelbert Humperdinck composed an opera adaptation of this Grimm’s fairy tale whose title children are turned into gingerbread by an evil witch.
answers: The Cunning Little Vixen [accept The Clever Little Vixen; or Tales of Vixen Sharp-Ears; or Příhody lišky Bystroušky]
“Hansel and Gretel” [accept “Little Step Brother and Little Step Sister”; “Hänsel und Gretel”; or “Hänsel und Grethel”]
formatted_answers: The Cunning Little Vixen [accept The Clever Little Vixen; or Tales of Vixen Sharp-Ears; or Příhody lišky Bystroušky]
“Hansel and Gretel” [accept “Little Step Brother and Little Step Sister”; “Hänsel und Gretel”; or “Hänsel und Grethel”]

bonuses.leadin: One of these two authors begged his muse to “Shut up thine olden pages, and be mute” in a sonnet about “sitting down to read” the other author “once again.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name these two authors, one of whom wrote of a quality which the other author possessed “so enormously” in a letter that coined the term “Negative Capability.”

R. S. White wrote that Antony’s plea on the barge to drink “Till that the conquering wine hath steeped our sense / In soft and delicate Lethe” influenced the first few lines of this Keats poem about an “immortal Bird.”

John Middleton Murry cited this event and Keats’s composition of “To Autumn” the same day as proof that “Shakespeare had triumphed in Keats’s soul.” In an 1819 letter, Keats explained that he made this decision because there had been “too many Miltonic inversions.”
answers: Keats’s abandonment of Hyperion [accept anything suggesting that Keats chose to leave Hyperion unfinished]
formatted_answers: Keats’s abandonment of Hyperion [accept anything suggesting that Keats chose to leave Hyperion unfinished]

bonuses.leadin: You are a physics graduate student struggling to complete their quantum field theory homework. For 10 points each:
parts: You are working on quantizing the relativistic wave equation named for this British physicist which describes spin-½ fermions. This equation’s namesake used it to theorize the existence of antimatter.

You first work out how these objects transform under simultaneous Lorentz transformations of their vector and spinor indices. Your professor introduced you to a nifty “slash notation” developed by Feynman to denote contraction with these objects.

You realize you must impose a relation based on this operation on the creation and annihilation operators of the Dirac theory. This operation applied to two gamma matrices is equal to two times the Minkowski metric.
answers: Paul Adrien Maurice Dirac [accept Dirac equation]
anticommutator [accept anticommutation relations; do not accept or prompt on “commutator” or “commutation relations”]
formatted_answers: anticommutator [accept anticommutation relations; do not accept or prompt on “commutator” or “commutation relations”]

bonuses.leadin: A curse from an escaped slave called Plato the Wizard was a popular explanation for the destruction of the town of Savanna-la-Mar in one of these events. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these events, several of which devastated the Caribbean in 1780. One of these events was named for José Solano centuries before the modern formal naming system.

This island was hit hard by the Great Hurricane of 1780, with one account claiming that it felled and stripped every tree of its bark. Many small landholders forced off their land by large sugar plantations moved from this British island to the Carolinas in the 1670s.
One of the 1780 hurricanes forced this man to abandon his attack on Pensacola during the American Revolution. As Viceroy of New Spain, this man ordered the construction of Chapultepec Castle.
answers: hurricanes [accept tropical cyclone or typhoon; prompt on cyclone]
Bernardo Vicente de Gálvez y Madrid, 1st Count of Gálvez
formatted_answers: Bernardo Vicente de Gálvez y Madrid, 1st Count of Gálvez

bonuses.leadin: This exegetical approach posits that there are four possible increasingly esoteric interpretations of the Torah, some of which rely on an alphanumeric code called “gematria.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this acronymic exegetical system. A legend about this system imagines rabbis entering a paradise of esoteric Torah knowledge due to the similarity between its name and the Hebrew word for “orchard.”
This chief Kabbalistic text, which modern scholars attribute to Moses de León rather than Shimon bar Yochai, is partially responsible for the popularization of the Pardes system.
The “pa” in “Pardes” is an abbreviation for peshat, a direct, literal method of exegesis that is defined in the portion of the Talmud defining laws related to this Jewish day of rest.
answers: Pardes [PaRDeS is an acronym for Peshat, Remez, Derash, and Sod]

bonuses.leadin: This museum, which is nicknamed “the Jewel Box” due to its symmetric rectangular shape, was designed by Jacob van Campen and Pieter Post. For 10 points each:
parts: Post’s Brazilian Landscape hangs in what museum in The Hague, which houses hundreds of paintings from the Dutch Golden Age? It was the private residence of a namesake prince of Nassau.
The room at the Maurtishuis dedicated to this artist contains his Saul and David, Simeon’s Song of Praise, and The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp.

Another room at the Mauritshuis is devoted to paintings of these objects, the specialty of Rachel Ruysch. Rembrandt lends his name to “broken” varieties of a specific kind of these objects, which are shot through with streaks of red or yellow.

bonuses.leadin: This modern country was once governed by an “oath alliance,” traditionally described as beginning with an oath on the Rütli meadow. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this modern country, whose cantons were joined in a confederacy until being defeated by Napoleon and formed into the Helvetic Republic.

The expansion of the Old Swiss Confederacy in the 14th century culminated in this 1386 battle with Austria. The Swiss victory at this battle is legendarily attributed to Arnold von Winkelried, who, by holding onto several enemy pikes, allowed the Swiss to break the Austrian line.

The Old Swiss Confederacy later fended off this ruler’s advances, earning a reputation that fueled the hiring of Swiss as mercenaries throughout Europe. This ruler organized the League of the Public Weal to counter Louis XI.
answers: Charles the Bold [accept Charles le Téméraire or Karl der Kühne; accept Charles Martin; prompt on Charles]
formatted_answers: Charles the Bold [accept Charles le Téméraire or Karl der Kühne; accept Charles Martin; prompt on Charles]

bonuses.leadin: Blogger Daniel Swain coined the term “Ridiculously Resilient Ridge” for a persistent anticyclone that contributed to one of these events. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these environmental catastrophes, one of which persisted between December 2011 to March 2017 in California, making the state more vulnerable to wildfires. October 2021 storms that brought about record rainfalls did not stop one that has been ongoing since 2020.

Due to low water levels, the current drought has necessitated the shutdown of the Hyatt power plant underneath this structure on the Feather River east of the Sacramento Valley, the tallest dam in the United States.
California droughts are somewhat exacerbated by water theft from producers in this industry, which particularly thrives in a “triangle” composed of Humboldt, Trinity, and Mendocino counties.
answers: cannabis [or marijuana; or pot; or weed; accept other colloquial synonyms]
formatted_answers: cannabis [or marijuana; or pot; or weed; accept other colloquial synonyms]

bonuses.leadin: This character instinctively reaches into his coat for a picture of a woman he had torn up long ago after recounting: “I could see disgust having a battle in her eyes with love. Love always won.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character who yells, “Well, you know what you can do with your pipe dream now, you damned bitch!” at the end of a long monologue in which he confesses to murdering his wife Evelyn.
Hickey’s arrival enervates the patrons of Harry Hope’s saloon in this play by Eugene O’Neill.

After hearing Hickey’s confession, the anarchist Hugo once more chants this six-word refrain, to which the patrons of the bar raucously shout the follow-up: “Tis cool beneath the willow trees!” as the curtain closes.

bonuses.leadin: Some Iris species experience a “combinatorial” form of this state, which is driven by both physiological conditions and physical attributes, like hard, impermeable seed coats. For 10 points each:
parts: Abscisic acid induces seeds and buds to enter what state, in which cells stop growing and germination does not occur?
Seed dormancy in Arabidopsis can be broken through stratification, in which this environmental stimulus is simulated. Prolonged exposure to this stimulus induces flowering in vernalization.

Reduced dormancy can be observed in mutants deficient in these molybdenum cofactor-containing enzymes, which transfer two electrons from NADH or NADPH to the namesake ion, then further catalyze the production of ammonia.
answers: dormancy [accept word forms such as dormant]
cold weather [or low temperatures; or chilling]
